briefOverview: Christ calls His followers to gather the elect and prepares them for imminent last‑days events, then teaches about judgment, agency, the Fall, and the redemption of little children.
summary: Jesus Christ forgives the addressed disciples, calls them to gather His elect to one place, and promises answers to united, faithful prayer. He foretells tribulations and cosmic signs preceding His coming, the destruction of the wicked, and a millennial reign when He will dwell with the righteous; the Twelve from Jerusalem will judge Israel, and a trumpet will announce the resurrection. Cataclysmic judgments—including hail, pestilence, and devouring by beasts—will be poured out on the unrepentant and the ‘great and abominable church’ will be cast down. After the Millennium, a brief apostasy will precede the end, the dissolution of the present heaven and earth, and the creation of a new heaven and new earth where nothing of God’s workmanship is lost. Michael will sound the trump, the dead will come forth, and final separation of righteous and wicked will occur. The Lord explains that all His laws are spiritual, creation proceeds by His Spirit, and agency is fundamental. He recounts Satan’s premortal rebellion, Adam’s Fall, the necessity of opposition, the plan of redemption through the Only Begotten, and declares that little children are redeemed and not accountable until they reach understanding; those with knowledge are commanded to repent.
externalContext: This revelation dates to September 1830 in upstate New York, early in the organization of the Church of Christ (later The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints). Early converts expected a literal gathering of believers to a designated place in preparation for Zion and the Lord’s return, an idea common in some restorationist and millenarian movements in the early American republic. The instruction to gather “upon the face of this land” reflects a North American setting and anticipates later directions to gather in Ohio and then Missouri. The text also responds to questions about agency, the Fall, and accountability, themes that were actively discussed among early Latter-day Saints.
externalReferences: The gathering image of a hen with her chickens echoes Jesus’ lament over Jerusalem (Matthew 23:37) and is paralleled in the Book of Mormon (3 Nephi 10:4–6). Apocalyptic portents—sun darkened, moon to blood, stars falling—align with Joel 2:31 and Revelation 6:12–13; the sounding trumpet and resurrection resonate with 1 Thessalonians 4:16, while the Millennium and the new heaven and new earth parallel Revelation 20:4–6 and 21:1. The casting down by devouring fire evokes Ezekiel’s oracles against hostile powers (Ezekiel 38–39), and the account of Satan’s rebellion and a third part of heaven corresponds to Revelation 12:4, 7–9. The necessity of opposition and accountability parallels 2 Nephi 2:11–16, and the declaration that little children are redeemed corresponds to Moroni 8:8–12.

sectionTitles.title: Signs and judgments before the coming

practicalQuestions: How can I participate in the spiritual and communal ‘gathering’ the Lord describes in my current context?
What practices of united, faithful prayer could I adopt to align with the promise in verse 6?
In what ways can I prepare spiritually for tribulation without becoming fearful or fixated on timelines?
How does viewing all commandments as spiritual (vv. 34–35) change the way I keep them?
What does the teaching about children’s accountability imply for how I teach, discipline, and support young people?
uncertainAreas: Exact identification of the Ezekiel passage behind verse 21 is not explicit. The degree to which the catastrophic judgments (vv. 14–20) are literal or symbolic is not stated. The scope and meaning of “never at any time have I declared…that they should return” (v. 29) relative to post-judgment repentance is not clarified in the text.
